title: Henry Hird
text:
Henry Hird (born 1874) was an English <a href="association%20footballer">association footballer</a> who played as a <a href="Midfielder%23Winger">winger</a>.
Football career.
Born in <a href="West%20Hartlepool">West Hartlepool</a>, Hird moved <a href="Southern%20England">south</a> to work for the <a href="Thames%20Ironworks%20and%20Shipbuilding%20Company">Thames Ironworks and Shipbuilding Company</a> as a <a href="Plating">plater</a> in 1897. He was a fast and tricky player renowned for his accurate <a href="Cross%20%28football%29">crosses</a> and described as "an out and out <a href="right%20winger">right winger</a>".
He joined Thames Ironworks for <a href="1897-98%20Thames%20Ironworks%20F.C.%20season">season 1897–98</a>, his high quality crosses contributed towards the Ironworks winning the <a href="London%20League%20%28football%29%23Division%20One%201897%E2%80%931898">1897–98 London League</a>. Hird is thought to be the first Ironworks player to have been <a href="sent%20off">sent off</a>. In his third game, a London League game against <a href="Leyton%20F.C.">Leyton</a> on 30 October 1897, Hird was <a href="Glossary%20of%20association%20football%20terms%23D">dismissed</a> by the <a href="Referee%20%28association%20football%29">referee</a> for disputing the awarding of a <a href="penalty%20%28association%20football%29">penalty</a>. He made just one appearance in the <a href="Southern%20Football%20League">Southern Football League Division One</a> and played for Ironworks until his last game on 14 October 1899. With this game, his career ended abruptly for an unknown reason.
